name: crhmsubcALTV
params: setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3
body: |- wi(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, cfv(csubc, cfv(cringcALTV, c0))))
-| wceq(c2, cmpo(s0, s1, c3, c3, co(cv(s0), crh, cv(s1))))

-| wral(s0, ccrg, wcel(cv(s0), crg))
-| wceq(c3, cin(c0, ccrg))
-| wceq(c2, cmpo(s0, s1, c3, c3, co(cv(s0), crh, cv(s1))))
-| diffss(s0, s1)

-| diffsc(s0, c3)

-| diffsc(s1, c3)
body.pretty:
⊢ (c0 ∈ c1 → c2 ∈(Subcat `(RingCatALTV ` c0)))
⊣ ∀(s0 ∈ CRing, s0 ∈ Ring)
⊣ c3 =(c0 ⋂ CRing)
⊣ c2 =(s0 ∈ c3, s1 ∈ c3 ↦(s0[RingHom]s1))
⊣ d(s0, s1)
⊣ d(s0, c0)

⊣ d(s0, CRing)
⊣ d(s0, c3)

⊣ d(s1, c3)

comment: According to ~ df-subc , the subcategories ` ( Subcat `` C ) ` of a category ` C ` are subsets of the homomorphisms of ` C ` (see ~ subcssc and ~ subcss2 ). Therefore, the set of commutative ring homomorphisms (i.e. ring homomorphisms from a commutative ring to a commutative ring) is a "subcategory" of the category of (unital) rings. (Contributed by AV, 19-Feb-2020.) (New usage is discouraged.)
